wikipedia_page.main: Sir Thomas Lopdell O'Shaughnessy (22 December 1850 – 7 March 1933) was the last Recorder of Dublin in Ireland.

response: *7 March – Thomas O'Shaughnessy, lawyer and judge (born 1850).
*22 December – Thomas O'Shaughnessy, lawyer and judge (died 1933).
Shootings took place in the square during Bloody Sunday of 1920. Sir Thomas O'Shaughnessy (1850–1933), the last Recorder of Dublin, lived in Fitzwilliam Square and died there on 7 March 1933.

The first man to hold the position was James Stanihurst, Speaker of the Irish House of Commons, in 1564, and the last was Sir Thomas O'Shaughnessy. The Recordership was abolished in 1924 and the Recorder's functions transferred to the new Circuit Court.Courts of Justice Act 1924 s.51
*1905-1924 Sir Thomas O'Shaughnessy (1850–1933)—the last Recorder of Dublin
